description: Welcome to the Microsoft MTA Security Fundamentals series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the 98-367 exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts such as exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes important topics like security layers, operating system security, network security, and security software.
descriptionMD: Welcome to the Microsoft MTA Security Fundamentals series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the 98-367 exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts such as exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes important topics like security layers, operating system security, network security, and security software.
name: MTA - Security Fundamentals  - 98-367 (2018)
subtitle: Security Fundamentals

episodes.description: Welcome to the Microsoft MTA Security Fundamentals series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the 98-367 exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts such as exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes important topics like security layers, operating system security, network security, and security software.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.598
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.598 --> 00:00:07.220
Hello, and thank you for watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.220 --> 00:00:10.475
I'm with Daniel Lowry, we're talking
about MTA security fundamentals.

4
00:00:10.475 --> 00:00:13.286
Daniel, nice to see you, can you tell
us what the course is all about?

5
00:00:13.286 --> 00:00:18.081
>> Yeah, sure, not a problem, the MTA
security fundamentals is all about, well,

6
00:00:18.081 --> 00:00:18.786
security.

7
00:00:18.786 --> 00:00:22.884
Hoping you get that start in that
security road down that field, so

8
00:00:22.884 --> 00:00:25.883
that you can start to
understand the concepts and

9
00:00:25.883 --> 00:00:30.220
practices inside of a Windows
environment when it comes to security.

10
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:32.243
That's what they're trying to do,
they're trying to build that foundation.

11
00:00:32.243 --> 00:00:35.674
So that as you become more and
more of a security practitioner,

12
00:00:35.674 --> 00:00:38.328
you have a solid set of skills,
understanding,

13
00:00:38.328 --> 00:00:42.234
and precepts to continue your
conversation with regards to security.

14
00:00:42.234 --> 00:00:44.604
>> So in a broader view,
who is the show targeted towards?

15
00:00:44.604 --> 00:00:49.206
>> That's a great question as well, it's
targeted toward people that wish to have,

16
00:00:49.206 --> 00:00:54.005
A, a really good foundational knowledge of
security practices in a Windows operating

17
00:00:54.005 --> 00:00:55.580
system environments.

18
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:58.750
So this will be Windows desktops,
as well as Windows servers.

19
00:00:58.750 --> 00:01:02.369
As well as the person that says,
you know what,

20
00:01:02.369 --> 00:01:08.210
I want to not only be an IT worker, but
I would like to focus in on security.

21
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:10.338
This will help you move
in towards your MCSA,

22
00:01:10.338 --> 00:01:12.303
if you intend to go
down that trek as well.

23
00:01:12.303 --> 00:01:15.407
>> Is there a certification
involved in this course?

24
00:01:15.407 --> 00:01:17.710
>> Yes, this is a certification course.

25
00:01:17.710 --> 00:01:22.731
We do have tech skill courses, but
this is one of our certification areas.

26
00:01:22.731 --> 00:01:26.887
Where you will, if you take the exam and
are able to successfully pass it,

27
00:01:26.887 --> 00:01:30.778
will receive a certification from
Microsoft that labels you an MTA,

28
00:01:30.778 --> 00:01:33.770
and says that you have
some security knowledge.

29
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:38.171
That way, you are able to show an employer
or any other person that wishes to ask,

30
00:01:38.171 --> 00:01:42.702
to be honest with you, about your security
knowledge, you can say, check it out,

31
00:01:42.702 --> 00:01:44.260
I'm MTA certified.

32
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:49.100
And we do need to understand some of
the minutiae when it comes to the exam.

33
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:51.640
So let's jump on to my
computer very quickly, and

34
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:55.560
let's take a look at Microsoft page
they gave us about the MTA exam.

35
00:01:55.560 --> 00:01:59.050
So here it is,
the exam number is the 98-367, so

36
00:01:59.050 --> 00:02:02.560
if you want to look it up by that,
that's totally fine.

37
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:05.710
It tells you when it was published, and
the languages that they offer it in.

38
00:02:05.710 --> 00:02:09.692
The audience, it's telling you, is a bit
academic, but hey, it's no problem for

39
00:02:09.692 --> 00:02:10.800
us, right?

40
00:02:10.800 --> 00:02:14.260
Technologies will be Windows 10,
even though it says Windows Server here.

41
00:02:14.260 --> 00:02:19.090
I will tell you, you will need to know
a bit about both, heavily on Windows 10,

42
00:02:19.090 --> 00:02:22.290
though, and
the Windows desktop environment, I'll say.

43
00:02:22.290 --> 00:02:24.377
>> And Daniel, what topics are covered
in MTA security fundamentals?

44
00:02:24.377 --> 00:02:26.113
>> That is a great question as well,

45
00:02:26.113 --> 00:02:30.210
I do wanna point out that you'll
notice that this does cost you money.

46
00:02:30.210 --> 00:02:34.670
It's right here, $127 US as of
the filming of this little overview for

47
00:02:34.670 --> 00:02:35.450
you good folks.

48
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:38.220
So if you're there, and
you can schedule with Certiport or

49
00:02:38.220 --> 00:02:41.680
Pearson VUE if you wanna go ahead and
take the exam, if you're ready for it.

50
00:02:41.680 --> 00:02:45.000
But the topics that are covered, tells
you right here, skills that are measured.

51
00:02:45.000 --> 00:02:48.590
You can read through that, but the
objectives that they give you will give

52
00:02:48.590 --> 00:02:52.270
you a really good understanding of
what's gonna be on the exam itself.

53
00:02:52.270 --> 00:02:56.260
And how much of the exam focuses
on each one of those domains.

54
00:02:56.260 --> 00:02:59.685
You have understand course security
principles, understand physical security,

55
00:02:59.685 --> 00:03:01.912
understand Internet security,
wireless security.

56
00:03:01.912 --> 00:03:03.967
And then it gives you some resources, and

57
00:03:03.967 --> 00:03:06.266
each one of these domains
will do that as well.

58
00:03:06.266 --> 00:03:10.688
Understand user authentication,
permissions, password policies,

59
00:03:10.688 --> 00:03:12.660
audit policies, encryption.

60
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:15.421
Malware, we're gonna cover all
this stuff in this series.

61
00:03:15.421 --> 00:03:18.655
Every one of these domains,
we will cover from stem to stern,

62
00:03:18.655 --> 00:03:19.976
no stone left unturned.

63
00:03:19.976 --> 00:03:24.251
Others that we have is network security,
so dedicated firewalls,

64
00:03:24.251 --> 00:03:26.952
network isolation, protocol security.

65
00:03:26.952 --> 00:03:29.832
And last but not least,
we have security software,

66
00:03:29.832 --> 00:03:34.280
which is client protection,
email protection, and server protection.

67
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:37.220
Those are the main bullet points that
we're gonna cover, and you can see,

68
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:39.510
there are subpoints underneath that.

69
00:03:39.510 --> 00:03:41.224
So look through this list,

70
00:03:41.224 --> 00:03:44.656
there is the URL right here
to help you get to this page.

71
00:03:44.656 --> 00:03:48.076
Or you can just search it on your
favorite search engine and look this up,

72
00:03:48.076 --> 00:03:51.518
go to this page right here, check it
out and make yourself a copy of this.

73
00:03:51.518 --> 00:03:55.897
It'll help you in your endeavor of making
sure you're on track when you're studying.

74
00:03:55.897 --> 00:03:59.139
>> Thanks Daniel, now, if MTA security
fundamentals sounds like something you

75
00:03:59.139 --> 00:04:01.018
should be interested in,
and you should be.

76
00:04:01.018 --> 00:04:05.069
Then make sure you see every single
episode inside of the course library, and

77
00:04:05.069 --> 00:04:06.825
thank you for watching ITProTV.

78
00:04:06.825 --> 00:04:12.974
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss the core security principles you'll need to be familiar with for the 98-367 exam. Here you will learn the basics about the CIA Triad, Threats, Risk, Vulnerabilities, Principle of Least Privilege, Social Engineering, Attack Surface Analysis, and Threat Modeling.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach take the time to explain common physical security concepts and practices. Here you will learn about Access Controls, Multifactor Authentication, Site Security, Mobile Device security, and removable drive/device security.
episodes.title: Physical Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore internet browser security, looking specifically at the Internet Explorer and Edge browsers. Here they will take you on a tour of security features such as Security Zones, Browsing History, Pop-up blockers, Certificates, and Advanced settings.
episodes.title: Internet Browser Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore internet browser security, looking specifically at the Internet Explorer and Edge browsers. Here they will take you on a tour of security features such as Security Zones, Browsing History, Pop-up blockers, Certificates, and Advanced settings.
episodes.title: Internet Browser Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach delve into Wireless security practices. They will explain the basics of wireless security and discuss the different types of wireless encryptions (WEP/WPA/WPA2) along with other security practices like disabling SSID broadcasts and MAC address filtering.
episodes.title: Wireless Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach delve into Wireless security practices. They will explain the basics of wireless security and discuss the different types of wireless encryptions (WEP/WPA/WPA2) along with other security practices like disabling SSID broadcasts and MAC address filtering.
episodes.title: Wireless Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore user authentication concepts and mechanisms. Here you will learn about how user authentication is accomplished using Kerberos, NTLM, and Single Sign-On(SSO).
episodes.title: User Authentication

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore user authentication concepts and mechanisms. Here you will learn about RADIUS, Multifactor authentication, physical and virutal smart cards, Biometrics, and the Run-As function.
episodes.title: User Authentication Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore securing your Windows filesystems and network shared objects by applying permissions. Here you will learn about the NTFS filesystem basic and advanced permissions. You will also learn about permission Inheritance and object Ownership.
episodes.title: Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore securing your Windows filesystems and network shared objects by applying permissions. Here you will learn about Delegation of control, behavior of permissions when copying vs moving an object, and what happens when permissions overlap.
episodes.title: Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore securing your Windows filesystems and network shared objects by applying permissions. Here you will learn about Delegation of control, behavior of permissions when copying vs moving an object, and what happens when permissions overlap.
episodes.title: Permissions Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explain the best practices with regards to Password Policies. Here you will learn about the different types of password attacks like Brute-Force and Dictionary. You will also learn how to use complexity and length to strengthen your passwords. Finally, you will learn about procedures like Lockouts, Resets, History, Age, and Auditing which will bolster your password security.
episodes.title: Password Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach help you how to understand Auditing in a Windows environment. Her you will learn about what can be audited, how to enable auditing, viewing Event logs, backing up audit information, and keeping audit logs secure.
episodes.title: Audit Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss Encryption. Here they will explain the encryption process as well as the differences between Private Key or Symmetric encryption vs Public Key or Asymmetric encryption. They also explain how Digital Signatures work.
episodes.title: Encryption

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach continue their conversation on encryption. Here they explore some of the ways we see encryption applied, ways like the Encrypting File System(EFS), BitLocker, PGP/GPG, Email, and IPSec VPNs.
episodes.title: Encryption Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach take a look at the basics of Digital Certificates. Here you will learn about the make-up of a Digital Cert, commonly used Certs along with where Certs are used, and how to create/acquire a Digital Certificate.
episodes.title: Digital Certificates

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach walk you through the exciting world of Malware. Here they will explore the different types of Malware that you may encounter as a security professional, including Viruses and Worms. They also explain the concept and implementation of a Buffer Overflow attack.
episodes.title: Malware

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach walk you through the exciting world of Malware. Here they will explore the different types of Malware that you may encounter as a security professional, including Trojan Horses, Spyware, Ransomware, Adware, Backdoors, and Zero-Day attacks.
episodes.title: Malware Part 2

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Zach explain the concept and use of
Dedicated Firewalls. Here they will explore the different types of firewalls, both host-based and hardware-based. They also discuss other firewall classifications such as packet filtering, Circuit-level, Application-level, UTM, Stateful, and Stateless. Lastly, they discuss Microsoft's Security Compliance Manager(SCM).
episodes.title: Dedicated Firewalls

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explain the use of Network Isolation as a security technique. Here they will go over the What and Why of isolation techniques like Routing, Perimeter networks, Network Address Translation, VPNs, Honeypots, and Microsoft's Domain Isolation Policy.
episodes.title: Network Isolation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore common protocol based attacks and protocol security. Here they will look at attack methods such as Man-in-the-Middle, ARP/DNS/IP Spoofing, Replays, SQL Injections, and Cross-Site Scripting(XSS). They also look at mitigation tactics like the use of Tunneling protocols and DNSsec.
episodes.title: Protocol Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach look at a few ways in which we can better protect our client operating systems using both 3rd-party and built-in Windows features. Here they will discuss Antivirus/Antimalware, removing unwanted applications/software, SmartScreen, User Account Control(UAC), and software updates.
episodes.title: Client Protection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss email protection. Here they will explain common email-based attacks like email spoofing, phishing, and pharming. They then go over ways to prevent email attacks using antispam, antivirus, Sender Policy Framework records, and PTR records.
episodes.title: Email Protection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore common techniques and best practices for protecting a server. Here they cover separation of services, physical security, server hardening, principle of least privilege, applying updates, and more.
episodes.title: Server Protection
